loans.name: Rukia's Ishalla Kher Group

texts.en: Rukia is 28 years old, and divorced with one child who is 6 years old. She has been a clothes, shoes and handbags seller since 2007. Every day, she works from 9am to 8pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $90 from her sales. In the past, Rukia has taken out one successful loan from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. Rukia now seeking a loan to increase her current stock to expand her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members Mwanajuma and Zamda.

loans.use: Rukia would like to increase her current stock for the expansion of her business.

loans.name: Asha

texts.en:
Asha is 32 years old. She is married with 3 children aged 12, 5 and 2 years old. She has been a potatoes and tomatoes seller since February 2008. Every day, she works from 9am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $125 from her sales.

Asha now looking for a loan to buy more potatoes and tomatoes for her business.

loans.use: To buy more tomatoes and potatoes for her business.

loans.name: Mtumwa's Mnyonge Hanuni Group

texts.en:
Mtumwa, 24 years old and married with one child aged two, has been a clothng and shoe seller since March of this year. She works everyday day at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $67 from her sales.

Mtumwa is now requesting a loan to buy more clothes and shoes for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who won a salon and a food vending business respectively.

loans.use: To buy more clothes and shoes for her business.

loans.name: Halima

texts.en: Halima is 22 years, and she is married with two children aged 1 and 3 years old. She has been a clothes and firewood  seller since May 2008. Every day, she works from 7am to 4pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $155  from her sales. Halima is now looking for a loan to buy more firewood and clothes for her business.

loans.use: Halima would like to buy more firewood and clothes  for her business.

loans.name: Fatma

texts.en:
Fatma  is 27 years old. She is married with 3 children ages between 6 months and 8 years old. She has been a charcoal and firewood seller since February 2008. Every day, she works from 7 am to 9 pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $140 from her sales.

Fatma now requests a loan to buy more charcoal and firewood to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal and firewood to expand her buisness.

loans.name: Zainab

texts.en:
Zainab is 33 years old and married with 2 children. She has been a charcoal seller since 2004. Every day, she works from 8AM to 6PM at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $80 from her sales.

In the past, Zainab has taken out 1 successful loan from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. Zainab is now looking for a loan to buy more charcoal for re-sale.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal for re-sale.

loans.name: Mwanajuma's Mkorofi Si Mwenzetu. Group

texts.en:
Mwanajuma is 29 years old and divorced with 2 children aged 14 and 7. She has been a food seller since 2000. Every day, she works from 9AM to 10PM at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $125 from her sales.

Mwanajuma now requests a loan to buy more food items for expansion of her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who also have businesses of selling food, charcoal, firewood, clothes, juice and snacks.

loans.use: To buy more food items for expansion of her business.

loans.name: Waride's Mkorofi Si Mwenzetu Group

texts.en:
Waride is married with 8 children between 18 and 6 years old. She has been a charcoal and juice seller since 2006. Daily she works at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $40 from her sales.

Waride now hopes for a loan to expand her business by adding to her current stock. She will share this loan with her subgroup members Frola and Sharifa, who also have businesses dealing with juice and snacks sales.

loans.use: To expand her business by adding her current stock.

loans.name: Amina's Tujivute Group

texts.en:
Amina is 45 years old. She is married with 4 children aged between 18 and 9 years old. She been a fish and clothes seller since 2002. Every day, she works from 6am to 8pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $125 from her sales.

In the past, Amina has taken out one successful loan from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. Amina now seeks a loan to buy more fish and clothes for re-sale. She will share this loan with her subgroup member Mtumwa, who has a business dealing with clothes and juice sales.

loans.use: To buy more fish and clothes for re-sale

loans.name: Miza

texts.en:
Miza is 35 years old. She is married with 5 children aged between 14 and 3 years old. She has been a charcoal and and bites seller since 2007. Every day, she works from 6am to 8pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $80 from her sales.

Miza now hopes for a loan to to expand her business.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Wanu

texts.en:
Wanu is 24 and she is married. She has run her own shop since February, 2008. Every day, she works from 6AM to 8PM at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $250 from her sales.

Wanu is now looking for a loan to buy more commodities for her business.

loans.use: To buy more commodities for her business.

loans.name: Adjala

texts.en:
Adjala I. is married and has 2 children. She has never received schooling. Adjala sells tarazo chippings in Abrobiano at Elmina. She buys the large rocks/stones and manually cracks them into smaller chippings for sale. Her major customers are building contractors.

Adjala has been doing this since 2006. Her husband is a mason. Adjala uses her income to pay housekeeping expenses and utility bills. Adjala will use the loan to purchase more tarazo chippings for re-sale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Adjala plans to save to reinvest into her business.

loans.use: to purchase more tarazo chippings for re-sale

loans.name: Peter

texts.en:
Peter M. is married and has 6 children. He has received schooling through junior high school. Peter is a commercial driver at Abrobiano in Elmina, a business he has been involved in since 1989. His wife is a merchant.

Peter uses his income to pay children's school fees and housekeeping expenses. Peter will use the loan to purchase spare parts for his car which has developed a fault. With the new profits from his expanded business, Peter plans to further expand his business.

loans.use: purchase spare parts for his car

loans.name: Hannah

texts.en:
Hannah A. sells cosmetics, shoes, and fabric at Kissi in Elmina. Hannah has received no formal education. She is a widow and has 2 children.

Hannah has been selling cosmetics, shoes, and fabric since 2006. She is responsible for paying her utility bills. Demand for her goods has increased and she is running out of stock. Her loan will be used to add to her capital to buy more cosmetics, shoes, etc. for re-sale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to save for reinvestment into her business.

loans.use: to add to her capital to buy more cosmetics, shoes, etc. for re-sale

loans.name: Hagai

texts.en:
Hagai E. sells rice, sugar, gari, tomatoes, and other products at Abrobiano in Elmina. Hagai has received senior high school education. She is divorced and has 2 children.

Hagai has been selling rice, sugar, gari, etc. since 1982. She is responsible for paying her children's school fees and for housekeeping expenses. Her loan will be used to add to her capital to buy more food items for sale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business for the expansion of her business.

loans.use: to add to her capital to buy more food items for re-sale

loans.name: Braima

texts.en: Braima A. is a fisherman and a trader at Abrobiano in Elmina. Braima has received no formal education. He is married and has 8 children. His wife is a trader. Braima has been a fisherman and a trader since 2006. He is responsible for paying utility bills and school fees. His loan will be used to buy fishing nets and fishing materials. He hopes to use the new profits from his business to build a family house.

loans.use: To buy fishing nets and fishing materials.

loans.name: Ali

texts.en: Ali, 24 years old and single, lives in a village in the Northern Bekaa. Ali owns a grocery shop where he also sells vegetables and fruit. Ali's enthusiasm and willpower have helped his business grow from day to day. Presently, he needs the amount of USD 1,200 to purchase goods and diversify his merchandise in order to make his business more solid and to expand it. This is the first time that Ali is requesting a loan from Al Majmoua.

loans.use: Diversify the grocery store merchandise

loans.name: Francis

texts.en: Francis H. is married and has 5 children. He has received schooling through junior high school. Francis a carpenter, he makes furniture at Abrobiano in Elmina, which he has done since 1996. His wife is a seamstress. Francis uses his income to pay for feeding of the family and the children's school fees. Francis will use the loan to purchase wood and carpentry tools. With the new profits from his expanded business, Francis plans to reinvest for the expansion of his business.

loans.use: Francis will use the loan to purchase wood and carpentry tools.

loans.name: Khayreddine

texts.en: Khayreddine, 34 years old and single, lives in a village in the Northern Bekaa. He owns a grocery shop where he also sells vegetables and fruits. Khayreddine has had a strong business relation with a couple of hospitals in his area as he supplies them with merchandise on a regular basis. This is the first time that Khayreddine has requested a loan from Al Majmoua. This loan will let him purchase more inventory and therefore improve his business by being able to provide a larger choice of goods. He needs a loan in the amount of USD 1,200. He promises to repay his loan on time.

loans.use: Purchase more inventory

loans.name: Noureddine

texts.en: Noureddine, a 37-year-old married man, father of 7 children, lives in a village in the Northern Bekaa. He owns a poultry butcher shop. His willpower and enthusiasm have helped his business grow every day. He has started to distribute chicken to a large number of restaurants and markets in the region. Presently he needs the amount of US$ 1,200 to improve the shop decoration. This is the first time that Noureddine is requesting a loan from Al Majmoua.

loans.use: Improve the shop decoration

loans.name: Veronica

texts.en: Veronica A. sells groceries such as biscuits, oats, milk, and other canned products at the Elmina market. Veronica has received no formal education. She is a widow and has one child. Veronica has been selling groceries since 2000. She is responsible for paying the school fees for her child, and housekeeping expenses. She plans to use the loan to buy bags of sugar, boxes of milk, and other items for resale. She hopes to save the new profits from her business to reinvest into her business.

loans.use: Buy bags of sugar, boxes of milk, and other items for resale

loans.name: Mohamad

texts.en: Mohamad, 32 years old, lives in a village in the Northern Bekaa. He is a hair designer for men. Mohamad is a very responsible man whose priority in life is the improvement of his business which is the only source of income for his family composed of his wife and 2 children. He needs a loan for an amount of US$ 1,200 to purchase new chairs for his shop. Mohamad has been a micro-credit client of A. Majmoua for the past 3 years and successfully repaid his loans on time.

loans.use: Purchase new hairdressing chairs

loans.name: Haytham

texts.en:
Haytham, 39 years old, married with 2 children, lives in a village in the Northern Bekaa. Haytham raises his children from the income generated by his business of aluminum installation.

Haytham is known in the area where he lives to be a specialist in this domain. He hopes to receive a loan in the amount of USD 1,200 to purchase a stock of aluminum. This inventory increase will allow Haytham to expand his business. This is the first time that Haytham is requesting a loan from Al Majmoua.

loans.use: Purchase a stock of aluminum

loans.name: Samiha

texts.en: Samiha A., 49 years old and single, lives with her elderly mother in a village in the Northern Bekaa Valley. Samiha owns a grocery shop, her only source of income, and is requesting a loan of $1,000 to purchase more merchandise so as to be able to offer a larger choice of products to her regular clients. This is Samiha’s first loan request from Al Majmoua.

loans.use: To purchase more merchandise

loans.name: Ahmad

texts.en:
Ahmad, 24 years old and single, lives in a village in the Northern Bekaa. Ahmad owns a mobile phone shop. He is the son of one of Al Majmoua's clients. His father's fruitful experience with Al Majmoua loans encouraged Ahmad to request for the first time a loan for himself.

Ahmad needs the amount of US$ 700 to purchase a stock of new mobile phones and rechargeable cards. This inventory increase will allow Ahmad to expand his business by attracting more customers.

loans.use: Purchase a stock of new mobile phones and rechargeable cards

loans.name: Ibrahim

texts.en: Ibrahim, 34 years old, a married man with no children yet, lives in a village in the Northern Bekaa. He is the proud owner of a small gas station on the village's main road. He needs a loan in the amount of US$ 1,200 to pay for gas pump maintenance and to purchase a stock of motor oil. This is the second time that Ibrahim is requesting a loan from Al Majmoua.

loans.use: Maintenance of the gas station and purchase of motor oil

loans.name: Zouhair

texts.en: Zouhair, 33 years old and engaged to be married, lives in the Bekaa Valley where he owns a car painting business. He is requesting a loan of $1,000 to pay for the expenses of his upcoming marriage. This is the first time that Zouhair has requested a loan from A. Majmoua.

loans.use: To pay for marriage expenses

loans.name: Alma

texts.es:
Doña Alma D. inicio su negocio hace alrededor de 5 años, cuando ella y su esposo deciden invertir el aguinaldo de el en comprar zapatos de un catalogo que pidió prestado, mismos que vendió entre sus familiares y amigos, como le fue muy bien en sus ventas, pudieron continuar pagando la colegiatura de sus hijos, y el dinero que les sobraba lo reinvertían en mas zapatos para poder obtener un poco mas de ganancias.

Alma D. solicita la cantidad de US $300 que pagara en 4 meses para comprar mercancia y ampliar un poco más su margen de utilidades y aumentar un poco mas sus ventas.
texts.en:
Alma D. started her business about 5 years ago, when she and her husband decided to invest his Christmas bonus in shoes from a catalogue that was loaned to him. They began selling shoes to friends and relatives, and because it went so well, they were able to pay for their children’s schooling. With the money leftover, they bought more shoes to continue their business.

Alma D. is asking for $300US, which she’ll repay in 4 months, to buy more merchandise, increase her profits and increase sales.

Translated from Spanish by Beatriz Yuste, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: comprar mercancia

loans.name: Juana

texts.es:
Juana B. Inicio su negocio hace aproximadamente 8 años en su inicio, comenzó vendiendo en el mercadito, primero solo eran pocas cosas como lentes cintos, gorras y artículos electrodomésticos pero cada vez que tenia la oportunidad de comercializar cosas nuevas las agregaba a su inventario por eso se fue haciendo de mas clientela y ahora vende también carriolas mochilas y ropa. Madre de 8 hijos, comenzó su vida de microempresaria poco antes de que su esposo falleciera, esto, aumento sus ganas de salir adelante ya que ahora no solo era ella la que tenia que sobrevivir, sino también sus hijos dos de los cuales seguían estudiando y requerían de un gasto extra debido a materiales escolares.

Doña Juana solicita el monto de US $575 que pagara en 6 meses para poder seguir con su negocio, los cuales utilizara para comprar pedidos que ya tiene con clientes y surtir mas mercancía innovadora.
texts.en:
Juana B. started her business about 8 years ago. She began by selling a few items in a small market: sunglasses, belts, caps and electrical appliances. But she added more products every time she had the chance, and with them the number of customers has grown. And now, besides other products, she sells baby carriages, backpacks and clothes.

Doña Juana is the mother of 8 kids, and she began this kind of business just before her husband died. Because of that her willingness to support her family grew stronger. She was the only parent now, and she still had two kids in school that needed books and other materials for their studies.

Doña Juana is asking for a loan of US$575 to continue in business. She would repay it in 6 months. The loan would be used to pay for orders of merchandise already required by customers, and for new items to sell.

Translated from Spanish by Marco Ramón, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy merchandise

loans.name: Maria Del Carmen

texts.es:
María del Carmen después de haber trabajado por mucho tiempo en una fábrica la señora Maria del Carmen decidió emprender su propio negocio, para solventar los gastos económicos de su hogar y sacar adelante a sus pequeños hijos, además por que casi no convivía mucho con sus hijos, por eso decidió poner su propio negocio. Poco a poco fue surtiendo de todo un poco en su dulcería, hasta hoy en día le ha ido muy bien tiene buenas ganancias, y muchos clientes.

Ella necesita un préstamo por US $950 que pagara en 6 meses para comprar mercancía y agrandar el local, ella confía que con el apoyo de Kiva lo obtendrá.
texts.en:
After María del Carmen had worked for a long time in a factory, she decided to start her own business. She needed to be able to pay for her household expenses, and the upbringing of her little kids. And she had another reason to start her own business, she wanted to spend more time with her kids. So, María del Carmen opened her candy store. Little by little she added more merchandise, different kinds of candies, and today she has a better income and a lot of customers.

María del Carmen needs a loan of US $950 that she'll repay in 6 months.This would be used to buy merchandise and to expand her store a little more. She is confident she would get it with Kiva's support.

Translated from Spanish by Marco Ramón, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: get merchandise

loans.name: Jesus Angel

texts.es:
Jesús inicio su negocio ya que necesitaba de un ingreso para solventar los gastos de su hogar y de sus 4 hijos: Juan Carlos de 6, Jesús Adrian de 4, María Guadalupe y María del Carmen R. Martínez de 2 años, empezó hace 3 años con la elaboración y venta de pan, empezó primero solo vendiendo a sus vecinos hasta que poco a poco se fue haciendo de clientes que lo recomendaron y logro tener un negocio mas prospero.

El necesita un préstamo por US $475 que pagara en 6 meses para comprar materia prima y así poder continuar con su negocio, con tu apoyo esto será posible.
texts.en:
Jesús started his business because he needed a steady income to support his family. He has 4 kids: Juan Carlos (6 years old), Jesús Adrián (4 y.o.) María Guadalupe y María del Carmen (2 y.o.). He began his business 3 years ago making bread and selling it himself. At the beginning his customers were only his neighbors, but little by little the business grew by word of mouth and he started to do better.

Jesús needs a loan of US $475 that he would repay in 6 months. He need it to buy raw materials and keep the business running. Your help would make this possible.

Translated from Spanish by Marco Ramón, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy raw materials

loans.name: Yesenia Marisol

texts.es:
Yesenia Marisol G. Z. vive en Ciudad Arce, departamento de La Libertad, y tiene dos hijos, un niño de seis y una niña de doce. Desde hace ya cuatro años, Yesenia junto a su suegra montaron un pequeña tienda, desafortunadamente, la suegra de Yesenia no puedo continuar ayudándole en la tienda, pues tiene diabetes, condición que le provoca muchos problemas de salud.
Con mucho esfuerzo, Yesenia Marisol ha sido capaz de mantener la tienda a flote, y hace dos meses, agrego una venta de tortillas y zapatos deportivos.  El préstamo que ella solicita, es para poder comprar mercadería como tortillas y zapatos. Este préstamo le permitiría a ella generar ingresos alternativos  y estabilizar su situación económica para poder proveer una mejor vida a sus hijos y suegra enferma.
texts.en:
Yesenia Marisol G. Z. lives in Ciudad Arce, La Libertad and has two children – a six-year-old boy and a twelve-year-old girl. For four years, Yesenia, together with her mother-in-law, managed a small store. Unfortunately, Yesenia’s mother-in-law cannot continue helping her in the store because she has diabetes, which causes many health problems.

With a lot of effort, Yesenia Marisol has been able to keep the store afloat, and two months ago, she began seling tortillas and sports shoes. The loan that she is requesting will allow her to purchase merchandise like tortillas and shoes. This loan will let her generate alternative sources of income and establish her economic situation so that she can provide a better life to her children and ill mother-in-law.

Translated from Spanish by Avni Shah, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy merchandise (tortillas and sports shoes)

location.town: Ciudad Arce en el departamento de La Libertad

loans.name: Mohammad Karim

texts.en:
M. Karim is married and has the sole responsibility for his family’s financial wellbeing.  He started his footwear business six years ago after leaving the military, and now wishes to expand it in order to become more profitable. He therefore is requesting a loan in order to enlarge his shop and expand his stock.

He is happy with this process whereby small loans to people in poor countries are possible.   Karim is sure that these loans can change the lives of many people and hopes to continue his partnership with Kiva and AFSG in Kabul so that eventually he can have one or two more shops.

He would like to thank the Kiva lenders who make this possible.

loans.use: To enlarge his shop and expand his stock

loans.name: Fatima

texts.en: Fatima is 44 years old, married, and has 4 children. Fatima lives in Beirut with her family and somehow finds the time to run a small grocery shop in her neighborhood. Fatima has requested a loan of $700 for the maintenance of her store. This will be Fatima's second loan with Al Majmoua.

loans.use: To fund necessary repairs at Fatima's grocery store

loans.name: Hussein

texts.en:
Hussein D. is a 45-year-old husband and father of 5. Hussein lives in the Southern Suburbs of Beirut, where he sews uniforms to help support his family.

With the arrival of the back-to-school season, Hussein needs to purchase a substantial stock of thread and other materials. He has requested a loan of US$ 1000 to fund this purchase. This will be Hussein's third loan with Al Majmoua. During his previous two cycles, he has always made his payments in full and on time.

loans.use: To purchase new sewing supplies for school uniform tailoring

loans.name: Adnan

texts.en:
Adnan is a husband and father of 3. He is 51 years old and lives in a suburb of Beirut that is frequently underserved by financial institutions and public services. Adnan owns a small cafe that provides a modest income for his family.

Adnan has been working in the bamboo industry before opening the coffee shop. In order to increase the household income, Adnan would like to purchase bamboo raw material so that with his wife, they can produce and sell bamboo items for which there is a demand especially for baskets. Adnan has requested $1,000 to purchase the material required. This is the fourth time Adnan has requested a loan from Al Majmoua. Adnan is a very serious borrower who has always repaid his debts on time.

loans.use: Purchase bamboo raw material

loans.name: Rabih

texts.en:
Rabih A. D. is 33 years old, single, and lives in the Southern Suburbs of Beirut. For a living, Rabih owns a store where he sells drinking water for the neighborhood. In Lebanon, tap water is not potable so generally people choose to purchase large containers of bottled water from their locA. markets and refill them at locA. shops.

Due to consistent electricity troubles, there are usually at least 3 hours each day without power, and Rabih has requested a loan of US$ 500 to buy a small generator. This will allow him to continuously run the pump system which fills customers' large water containers. This is the third time Rabih will be working with A. Majmoua. His previous two loans were each repaid on time.

loans.use: To purchase a small generator for power outages

loans.name: Abdallah

texts.en:
AbD. is 37 years old, married and a father of 3. He lives in the Southern suburbs of Beirut. AbD. owns a small bakery shop which specializes in making a traditional type of Lebanese bread called "Manakesh". This flat, round bread fits in the hand when rolled up, and is often covered with the thyme-like Lebanese herb "Zaatar," cheese, or meat.

AbD. has asked Al Majmoua for a loan of $1000 in order to repair his bread-baking oven. This loan will help AbD. to continue satisfying his costumers with his delicious Manakesh. AbD. has built a solid relationship with Al Majmoua, and this will be his fourth loan.

loans.use: To finance repairs on Abdallah's bread oven

loans.name: Bassam

texts.en: Bassam C. is 29 years old, married and the father of 2. He lives in Burj Al Barajneh, a neighborhood in the Southern Suburbs of Beirut. Bassam works as a tailor, altering and mending clothes. He has asked Al Majmoua for a loan of $1000 to purchase a vehicle. This is the third time Bassam has requested a loan from Al Majmoua.

loans.use: To help purchase a vehicle

loans.name: Bashir

texts.en: Bashir R. is 25 years old, single, and lives in the Southern Suburbs of Beirut. Bashir owns a small store where he sells various perfumes, gifts, and accessories. Bashir is asking for a loan of $1000 to purchase more products for his store in order to keep pleasing his customers. This is the third time Bashir has requested a loan from Al Majmoua.

loans.use: To help expand and diversify his product offerings

loans.name: Mashhour

texts.en: Mashhour N. lives in the Southern Suburbs of Beirut. Mashhour is 35 years old, married and has 4 children. Mashhour is a striving butcher and has requested a loan of US$ 1,200 to improve and expand his business. This is the second loan Mashhour has requested from Al Majmoua.

loans.use: To purchase new stock and tools to expand his butcher shop

loans.name: Rabih

texts.en: Rabih A., 33 and married with five children, lives in the southern suburbs of Beirut, where he manufactures shoes. Rabih needs to buy a new supply of leather and other materials for his business, and is therefore requesting a loan of $1200 for that purpose. This is the second time Rabih will have received a loan from Al Majmoua.

loans.use: To purchase a large inventory of materials for Rabih's shoe-making business

loans.name: Hussein

texts.en:
Hussein K. is 36 years old, single, and lives in the Southern Suburbs of Beirut. He owns a small shop where he sells "nargileh," the traditional and very popular Lebanese water pipe used for smoking tobacco, or "sheesha," of various flavors.

Hussein is asking for a US$ 700 loan in order to purchase new nargileh and various accessories for his store. This is the first time Hussein has requested a loan from Al Majmoua.

loans.use: To purchase new stock of "Nargileh" for his store

loans.name: Rola

texts.en: Rola K., 29 years old and the mother of one child, lives in Northern Lebanon close to the town of Baalback.  A very active woman who works as a hair dresser, her creative mind is always searching for ways to better develop her shop.  Rola is requesting a $500 loan from Al Majmoua to purchase various new hairdressing tools including scissors and hairdryers. This will be Rola's first loan with Al Majmoua.

loans.use: To purchase new hairdressing tools

loans.name: Mounira

texts.en:
Mounira S. is 41 years old, married, and has 3 children. She lives in a small village located in Northern Lebanon, close to Baalback. Mounira is an energetic woman who has a mini-market in town which sells many household staples such as bread and oil, as well as fresh chicken.

Mounira has asked Al Majmoua for a loan of US$ 1200 to purchase a more diverse array of goods for her shop. Mounira has been a client of Al Majmoua for the past 4 years.

loans.use: To diversify product offerings at Mounira's mini-market

loans.name: Muhammad

texts.en:
Muhammad K. is 56 years old and the father of 6 children. He lives in in a small village located in the north of Lebanon's Bekaa Valley. Muhammad owns and operates a generator that supplies electricity to houses in the neighborhood.

While most houses and businesses in this region are connected to the electric grid, Lebanon typically sees at least 3 hours per day of outages and many rely on local generators for alternative power.

Muhammad has been a client of Al Majmoua for the past 5 years and has asked for a loan of US$ 1200. It has been a lifelong wish of Muhammad to see his son get married, and finally the day has arrived. The money from this loan will be used to help pay for his son's upcoming wedding ceremony and complete construction on the home of this groom-to-be.

loans.use: To help with the costs of a son's wedding

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth G. operates a grocery store in her neighborhood. She started her operation twenty years ago at Obuasi where she lives with her ten children. She is a 41-year-old mother with six of the kids currently in school. She sells products like rice, canned foods and drinks, assorted cooking oil, assorted biscuits, candies, evaporated milk and also sells popcorn, etc.

With the loan, she wants to buy cartons of evaporated milk, bags of rice and popcorn maize, canned foods and drinks, and cooking oil to increase her stock of goods. With an increased stock of different varieties, she hopes to make more income to provide for the educational needs of her children. She would appreciate very much your assistance. She is a member of the group called "Debora Mma" Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee for one another as social collateral to access loan and peer pressure to repay the loan.

loans.use: To buy cartons of evaporated milk, bags of rice, canned foods and drinks, cooking oil, maize, etc.

loans.name: Ali

texts.en:
A. A. is 58 years old and married with 7 children. A. lives in a small village located in Northern Lebanon, close to town of Baalback. He owns a mini-market in town which sells various necessities for the Lebanese home, such as olive oil, bread, and cheese.

A. wishes to improve the quantity and diversity of his merchandise and has asked for a loan of US$ 1200 to help him purchase the necessary products and refrigerators. A. has been a client of Al Majmoua for the past 7 years.

loans.use: To help purchase new products and cold storage for Ali's small market

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes S., a 58-year-old businesswoman is widowed with five children. Among these children, two are still in senior high school. She is a very resourceful salesperson and mother whose hard effort brings livelihood to the family.

Agnes provides for the household through the sale of used clothing and shoes. Selling of used clothing is a very big market in Ghana as brand-new clothes are too expensive for the economically active poor. Therefore the selling of used clothing has created a market for many women.

Agnes wants to use this loan to buy more bales of used clothing and shoes to increase her inventory. She believes this loan will help her save for her children's future education and also rent a store to sell her goods out of. She is a member of the group called "Nkwa Nsuo" meaning Living Waters. Members agree to guarantee for each other as social collateral to repay the loan.

loans.use: To buy more bales of used clothing and shoes

loans.name: Irene

texts.en:
Irene M., 26 years old and single, is a hard-working young woman who has been sewing for three years. She is a specialist in women's and kids' wear. Her skills and designs are in a class by themselves. She sews various kinds of styles that give her customers a new look, like kaba and slit, wedding dresses, funeral clothes, kids' wear etc. She also sews children's school uniforms for most of the schools in Obuasi as a subsidiary to give her extra income to support her business.

Irene wants to use the loan to buy supplies of sewing materials like linen, thread, thimbles, and lace materials, etc. to increase her output and efficiency. She hopes to increase her savings to provide for herself. She is a member of the community group called Divine Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee for one another as social collateral to access and repay the loan.

loans.use: To buy supplies of sewing materials to increase her output and efficiency

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
For the past eight years, Elizabeth O., a 53-year-old single woman with four children in school, has been trading in the local market of Obuasi in Ghana.  She sells palm kernel oil, vegetable oil, tinned tomatoes, yams, onions, beans, maize, dried fish, etc. at her market location. 

Elizabeth is requesting a loan in order to further develop her business,  planning to purchase good quality stock to upgrade her inventory. She says that she would be grateful for your assistance. Elizabeth is a member of the group called Divine, whose members agree to guarantee and support one another in the repayment of the loan.

loans.use: To purchase more palm kernel oil, vegetable oil, tinned tomatoes, yams, onions, beans, dried fish, etc.

loans.name: Dora

texts.en:
Dora O., a 45-year-old a widow with three children, is a very dedicated owner and operator of a grocery shop selling such items as rice, evaporated milk, canned foods, drinks, assorted cooking oil, washing powder, toilet soaps, and candies in Obuasi, where she lives. Dora supports her family with proceeds from her business. 

She is requesting a loan to purchase bulk supplies of grocery goods in order to expand her business. Dora O. hopes to thereby save more towards her children’s education. She belongs to the group called 'Jesus loves you Trust Group', whose members guarantee and support one another to repay their loans on time.

loans.use: To purchase more canned foods, drinks, milk, assorted spices, washing soaps, etc. for her store

loans.name: Naseem's Group

texts.en:
Naseem baji is the wife of Mr.S. and the mother of three children: two sons and one daughter. She lives in a small city named Chichawatni, Pakistan. She owns a two-room brick house and has been living in it for the last 20 years. Her elder son is in kindergarten. Her husband is a wheat seller and has been in this profession for the last 10 years. Naseem baji successfully repaid her first loan from Asasah (a microfinance institute in Pakistan). She used that loan for her husband's wheat business. Now she is applying for a loan again for her husband's wheat business.

She is joined in her loan group by several more members. Mukhtaran baji wants a loan to buy material (cloth, thread) for her decorative embroidery business. Munawar baji wants a loan to buy eatable things (chips) to re-sell. Irshad baji and Manzooran baji each want a loan to buy fruit to re-sell.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy more wheat to re-sell

loans.name: Mi

texts.en: Mrs. Mi Y. is a villager in Vihea Village in Kandal Province. She is a farmer who cultivates twice a year. It is now the rainy season so she needs to cultivate rice; unfortunately, Mrs. Mi Y. does not have enough money to hire a laborer to plow the rice field, thus, she decided to ask for a loan for this purpose. She will use the rest of the loan to buy more rice seeds for cultivating. Her husband, Mr. Nat Noeurn, is a fisherman and pig breeder. Mrs. Mi Y. is 37 years old and the mother of four children, three of whom are attending school while the youngest one is only four years old and is too young to study. Her husband is on the right of the photo.

loans.use: To hire a laborer to plow the rice field and to buy more rice seeds

loans.name: Chut

texts.en: Mrs. Chut S. was born in 1978 and she now lives in Ankg Village in Kandal Province. She is a silk weaver who weaves silk together to process into silk fabric. Aside from this business, she is a farmer. Since it is now the rainy season, Mrs. Chut S. needs to cultivate rice, so she decided to ask for a loan to hire laborers to work on the field. In addition, she will use the rest of the loan to purchase fertilizer and fuel to make her crop more productive. Her husband, Mr. Noem Noeurn, is a middleman who buys chickens and then re-sells them at a better price. Mrs. Chut S. is 30 years old and the mother of three children who are all attending school.

loans.use: To hire laborers to work on the field and to purchase fertilizer and fuel

loans.name: Houn

texts.en: Mrs. Houn L. was born in 1966 and she now lives in Chek Village in Kandal Province. She and her husband, Mr. Chu Sun, are fishermen. They can no longer gather much fish because their boat is too old. Mrs. Houn L. decided to ask for a loan to buy a new boat in order to re-start her business. Additionally, Mrs. Houn L. would use the rest of the loan to purchase more fish nets. Mrs. Houn L. is 42 years old and the mother of three children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory while another one is a singer who typically sings at wedding ceremonies. The youngest one is attending the local school. Her husband is on the left of the photo.

loans.use: To buy a new boat and more fish nets

loans.name: Trading Goods/retail And Livestock Group

texts.vi:
Chị Sáu năm nay 44 tuổi . MS: 13.03.0038. Với mức vay : 3.186.000 đồng
Chị Sáu vay vốn để đi chợ và chăn nuôi, gia đình chị gồm có 6 người. Chị có hai con đang đi học, chồng chị cũng đi chợ. Thu nhập hàng ngày của gia đình chị khoảng 200.000đ/tháng. Chí là thành viên mới tham gia vào chương trình. Chị rất thích cách vay của chương trình vi hàng tuần gia đình chị có thể trả dễ dàng, phù hợp với mục đích của gia đình chị.  
Trong nhóm chị gồm có :
+ Nguyễn Thị Hà : 30 tuổi . MS : 13.03.0039 . Mức vay  3.186.000 đồng
Chị Hà vay vốn về để đi chợ và chăn nuôi.
+ Đào Thị Dung: 26 tuổi. MS : 13.03.0040. Mức vay : 3.186.000 đồng
Chị Dung vay vốn để kinh doanh  và đi chợ bán thịt bò.
+ Trần Thị Thu: 54 tuổi. MS : 13.03.0042. Mức vay: 3.186.000đồng
Cô Thu vay vố để buôn bán gạo và chăn nuôi.
+Nghiêm Thị Hồng: 26 tuổi. MS: 13.03.0041. Mức vay: 3.186.000 đồng
CHị Hồng vay vốn về để đi chợ và chăn nuôi.
texts.en:
Mrs. Sau Thi T. is 44 years old. With a loan amount of 3,186,000 VND, Mrs. T. would like to trade goods and raise livestock. Her family includes 6 people. She has two children, and her husband also trades goods. Their average daily income is about 200,000 VND per month. Mrs. Sau is a new participant to the program. She really likes this loan method of the program because her family can easily make the weekly payment, and it is a good fit with her family's goals. Her group also includes: Mrs. Ha Thi N., 30 years old, borrowing 3,186,000 VND to do trading and raise livestock; Mrs. D. Thi Dung, 26 years old, borrowing 3,186,000 VND to use a capital for her business and sell beef; Mrs. Thu Thi T., 54 years old, borrowing 3,186,000 VND to do business selling rice and raise livestock; Mrs. Hong Thi N., 26 years old, borrowing 3,186,000 VND to trade goods and raise livestock.

Translated from Vietnamese by Chi N., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Trade goods and raise livestock

loans.name: Trading Goods, Livestock Group

texts.vi:
Tô Thị Lợi 28 tuổi. MS: 13.03.0032. Vay : 3.186.000 đồng
Chị Lợi vay vốn để đi chợ, gia đình chị chở hàng để nuôi ba đứa con ăn học. Gia đình chị có thu nhập hàng  ngày khoảng từ 300.000đồng / ngày. Chị là thành viên mới, chị thích vay vốn của chường trình để thêm vốn trong công việc kinh doanh của gia đình. Với cách trả hàng tuần của Chương trình gia đình chị thấy hợp lý vì có thể tiết kiệm và trả dễ dàng hơn.
Trong nhóm chị gồm:
<li> Đào Thị Huyền 25 tuổi . MS 13.03.0031. Vay 3.186.000 đồng. Chị Huyền vay vốn để đi chợ và chăn nuôi.
<li> Nghiêm Thị Mai 24 tuổi. Ms: 13.03.0033. Với mức vay :3.186.000đồng. Chị Mai vay vốn để đi chợ và xây chuồng để chăn nuôi.
<li> Lê Thị Tuất: 49 tuổi. MS: 13.03.0034. Vay 3.186.000đồng. Cô Tuất vay vốn để đi chợ bán thị và chăn nuôi.
<li> Trần Thị Tươi 23 tuổi. MS: 13.03.0035. Mức vay: 3.186.000 đồng. Chị Tươi vay vốn để chăn nuôi và làm nghề mộc.
<li> Tô Thị Hợi:  24 tuổi. MS: 13.03.0036. Mức vay 3.186.000 đồng. Chị Hợi vay vốn để đi chợ, chị buôn bán rau, củ, quả.
<li> Trần Thị Vượng 49 tuổi. Ms: 13.03.0037. Mức vay 3.186.000 đồng. Cô Vượng vay vốn để chăn nuôi và làm giấy.
texts.en:
Mrs. Loi Thi T., 28 years old, is borrowing 3,186,000 VND T. do business trading goods. Her family currently works in transporting goods T. have money T. take care of and send her three children T. school. The family's average daily income is a minimum of about 300,000 VND per day. She is a new participant, and likes the method of borrowing from the loan program T. have more capital for the family's business. With the weekly repayment plan, the family sees that it is a good fit because it allows them T. save money and repay much easier. Her group also includes: Mrs. Huyen Thi D., 25 years old, borrowing 3,186,000 VND T. trade goods and raise livestock; Mrs. Mai Thi N., 24 years old, borrowing 3,186,000 VND T. trade goods and build a pen for raising livestock; Mrs. Tuat Thi L., 49 years old, borrowing 3,186,000 VND, T. trade goods and raise livestock; Mrs. Tuoi Thi T., 23 years old, borrowing 3,186,000 VND T. raise livestock and do woodwork; Mrs. Hoi Thi T., 24 years old, borrowing 3,186,000 VND T. trade goods, sell vegetables; Mrs. Vuong Thi T., 49 years old, borrowing 3,186,000 VND T. raise livestock and make paper.

Translated from Vietnamese by Chi Nguyen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Trade goods, raise livestock

loans.name: Mrs. Sam Sambath Village Group

texts.en:
FourteE. people in Chrolong Village in Kampong Chhnang Province have formed a village bank, and are asking for a loan which they will use for different purposes. Mrs. Sam S. is the village bank president and she breeds cows. Her husband, Mr. Yean Saly, is a fisherman in the local lake. Unfortunately, he can no longer fish because his boat is too old. In order to restart this business, his wife, Mrs. Sam S. decided to ask for a loan for a new boat for her husband's business. Mrs. Sam S. is 39 years old and the mother of six childrE., one of whom is employed in a garment factory while another one is a fisherman. The other three attend school, while the youngest one is only four years old. Mrs. Sam S. was too busy with her work, so her husband is shown in the photo. 

This is a village bank loan consisting of mainly end-of-term loans. Twelve members have end-of-term loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. These members are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK's main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia's poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to repay. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK's clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To buy a new boat

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Livestock, Making Food Products, And Trading Goods Group

texts.vi:
C. Thị Xuân năm nay 50 tuổi. Ms: 13.03.0020. Vay 4.704.000 đồng.
Cô Xuân vay vốn về để kinh doanh của cửa hàng cô. Gia đình cô bán hàng tại nhà muốn thêm vốn bán ra nhiều loại hàng hoá. Cô có 3 người con, đứa lớn đã đi lấy chồng, còn hai đứa vẫn đang đi học. Hai vợ chồng bán hàng ở nhà và chăn nuôi thêm. Gia đình cô thu nhập khoảng 300.000đồng / ngày. 
Trong  nhóm bao gồm:
<li> Vũ Thị Tỷ: 53 tuổi. Ms 13.03.0024. Vay 4.256.000đồng. Cô Tỷ vay vốn về để đi chợ và làm nghề đan tre nứa.
<li> Tô Thị Hoa: 32 tuổi. Ms: 13.03.0022. Vay: 4.256.000 đồng. Chị Hoa vay vốn về để làm nghề tráng bánh đa nem và chăn nuôi lợn gà.
<li> Trần Thị Ngà: 43 tuổi. Ms: 13.03.0032. Vay 3.360.000 đồng. Cô Ngà vay vốn để đi chợ buôn bán mặy hàng tre nứa.
<li> Lê Thị Canh: 43 tuổi. Ms : 13.03.0021. Vay : 4.256.000 đồng. Cô Canh vay vốn để làm nghề tráng bánh đa nem và chăn nuôi.
<li> Đinh Thị Thêm: 35 tuổi. Ms : 13.03.0025. Vay 4.256.000 đồng. Chi Thêm vay vốn mục đích để đi chợ buôn bán mỳ và chăn nuôi.
texts.en:
Mrs. Xuan Thi C., 50 years old, is borrowing 4,704,000 VND T. use as capital for her store. Her family runs a small store out of their home selling general goods, and they would like T. use the money T. expand the variety of goods they sell. She has three children, the oldest of which has married a husband, and the remaining two are still in school. She and her husband raise livestock in addition T. running their store. Her family's income is about 300,000 VND per day. The group also includes: Ty Thi V., 53 years old, borrowing 4,256,000 VND T. do business trading goods and also do bamboo weaving; Hoa Thi T., 32 years old, borrowing 4,256,000 VND T. make rice wrappers for eggrolls and raise livestock; Mrs. Nga Thi T., 43 years old, borrowing 3,360,000 VND T. do business trading bamboo goods; Mrs. Canh Thi L., 43 years old, borrowing 4,256,000 VND T. make eggroll wrappers and raise livestock; Mrs. Them Thi D., 35 years old, borrowing 4,256,000 VND T. do business selling noodles and raise livestock.

Translated from Vietnamese by Chi Nguyen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Capital for trading goods, raising livestock, and various food manufacturing activities

loans.name: Nadia's Group

texts.en:
Nadia baji, the wife of N. S., lives in an area of Lahore, Pakistan named Ismail Nagar where she has resided in her two room brick house for the last three years. A housewife who completed her education to 12th standard, Nadia baji prefers to concentrate on housework and teaching her four sons, the eldest of whom is in 3rd standard while the others are in kindergarten. Her husband has a burger joint which he has operated for the past 15 years. She fully repaid her three previous loans from Asasah (a microfinance institution in Pakistan) and now is applying for a loan to buy chairs, tables, and tablecloths for her husband's burger joint in order to provide his customers with a better service.

She is joined in her loan group by four other members: Rashida baji wants a loan to buy biscuits and sweets to resell; Asifa baji wants to buy utensils for her food business; Irshad baji wants to buy scrap (iron, papers, and plastic bottles) for her scrap business, and Shahnaz baji wants a loan to buy lentils, cooking oil, and rice for her food business.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy furnishings for her husband's hamburger joint

loans.name: Parveen's Group

texts.en:
Parveen baji, the wife of A. R., lives in an area of Lahore, Pakistan named Ismail Nagar. Concentrating on household work, she has resided in her seven room brick house for the last 35 years, raising eight children: seven sons and one daughter. Her eldest son operates his own clinic, while the next eldest works in a factory. Four other sons make artificial jewelry sets that they sell in the market, while her youngest son is in 6th standard and her daughter is in 9th standard. Parveen baji's husband is unemployed. 

Parveen baji fully repaid her three previous loans from Asasah (a microfinance institution of Pakistan) and is now requesting a loan to buy material (beads, wires, tools) for her sons’ jewelry-making business. 

She is joined in her loan group by four other members:  Farhat baji wants a loan to buy seasonal fruits to resell; Nargis baji wishes to buy livestock (goats) for her meat business; Razia baji wants to purchase material (beams, rope) for her shuttering business, while Ruqaiya baji wants a loan to repair her auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To make artifical jewelry sets

loans.name: Livestock, Making Food Products, And Trading Goods Group

texts.vi:
Tô Thị Đào: 45 tuổi. Ms : 13.03.0026. Mức vay: 4.704.000. Cô Đào vay vốn về để mua đậu tương làm đậu phụ mang ra chợ bán. Nhà cô vừa làm nghề đậu vừa chăn nuôi lợn. Cô có hai dứa con đang học đại học. Thu nhập bình quân của gia đình cô khoảng 100.000 đồng/ ngày. Cô đã lo toan công việc hàng ngày vất vả nhưng cô vẫn tham gia làm trưởng nhóm của chương trình, vì cô rất thích chương trình tạo cho cô có thêm vốn để làm ăn và cách trả cũng phù hợp với gia đình cô. 
Trong đó:
<li> Ngô Thị Miên: 49 tuổi. Ms: 13.03.0027. Vay mức: 4.256.000đồng. Cô Miên vay vốn về để làm bún và chăn nuôi.
<li> Trần Thị Mai: 45 tuổi. Ms: 13.03.0028. Vay mức: 4.256.000đồng. Chị Mai vay vốn về để chăn nuôi và đi chợ bán hoa quả.
<li> Dương Thị Thuỷ: 38 tuổi. MS: 13.03.0030. Vay : 4.256.000 đồng. Chị Thuỷ vay vốn về để làm bánh đa nem và chăn nuôi.
<li> Trần Thị Loan: 25 tuổi. MS: 13.03.0029. Vay 3.808.000đồng. CHị Loan vay vốn để đi chợ , lúc rảnh rỗi chị phụ chồng đi lam thợ xây.
texts.en:
Mrs. Dao Thi T., 45 years old, is borrowing 4,704,000 VND T. buy soybeans T. make tofu and sell it at the market. Her family also keeps livestock in addition T. the tofu business. She has two children who are in college. The family's average income is about 100,000 VND per day. She has had many difficulties in managing the many daily tasks of the business, but is still participating in the program as a group leader because she really enjoys the opportunities that the loan money has brought her, and also thinks the repayment method is a great fit with the family. Her group includes: Mrs. Mien Thi N., 49 years old, borrowing 4,256,000 VND T. make rice noodles and raise livestock; Mrs. Mai Thi T., 45 years old, is borrowing 4,256,000 VND T. raise livestock and sell fruits; Mrs. Thuy Thi D., 58 years old, borrowing 4,256,000 VND T. make eggroll wrappers and raise livestock; Mrs. Loan Thi T., 25 years old, borrowing 3,808,000 VND T. do business trading goods, in her spare time she also helps her husband in his construction work.

Translated from Vietnamese by Chi Nguyen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Capital for trading goods, raising livestock, and various food manufacturing activities

loans.name: Syeda Sarwat Parveen's Group

texts.en:
Sayeda Sarwat Parveen baji, the wife of S. K. A., has lived for the last 18 years in an area of Lahore, Pakistan called Ismail Nagar. Preferring to do household work and take care of her family, she is the mother of four sons, two in 10th standard, one in 7th standard and the youngest in 4th standard. Her husband has run a small hotel with an eatery in the community for the past four years. Sayeda baji is now requesting a loan to buy cooking materials (lentils, cooking oil, spices) for her husband's food business. She is joined in her loan group by two other members: Shahnaz baji wants a loan to buy beams and rope for her shuttering business, while Shazia baji wishes to purchase seasonal fruits to resell.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible

loans.use: To buy cooking materials for the food business

loans.name: Rubina's Group

texts.en:
Rubina baji, the wife of M. A., lives in an area of Lahore, Pakistan called Ismail Nagar. Preferring to do household work and take care of her family, she has resided in her two room brick house for the last 17 years, the mother of three children: two sons and one daughter. Her eldest son is a tailor by profession while her other son is in 3rd standard and her daughter is in 2nd standard. Rubina baji's husband is a tailor by profession with 35 years of experience. \t Rubina baji fully repaid her first loan from Asasah (a microfinance institution of Pakistan) and is now applying for a new loan to buy a sewing machine for her husband. She is joined in her loan group by four other members: Parveen baji wants a loan to buy beams and rope for her shuttering business; Suraiya baji wants to purchase seasonal fruits to resell; Ghafooran baji wishes to repair an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled vehicle), while Tahira baji wants a loan to buy more meat to resell.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy a sewing machine

loans.name: Yasmeen's Group

texts.en:
Yasmeen baji, the wife of G. N., has been living in an area of Lahore, Pakistan called Ismail Nagar for the last 17 years. She is the mother of four children: two sons and two daughters. Her eldest son works in 'PEL' (a famous electronics company) while her other son is in 7th standard. Her daughters are in 10th standard. Yasmeen baji's husband has been a driver by profession for the last five years, while she has operated a business selling clothes for the last 10 years. Yasmeen baji fully repaid her first loan from Asasah (a microfinance institution of Pakistan) and is now requesting a loan to buy more clothes to resell.

She is joined in her loan group by five other members. Sabra baji and Shahnaz baji each want a loan to buy clothes to resell; Sugran baji and Rani baji each want to buy material (woods and wood polisher) for their furniture making business, while Kubra baji wants a loan to buy more clothes to resell.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to resell

loans.name: Mtumwa's Bora Utu Group

texts.en:
Mtumwa is 28 and married with 3 children aged 11, 8 and 6. She has been a charcoal, firewood and snacks seller since 2007. Every day she works at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $80 from her sales.

Mtumwa now hopes for a loan to expand her business by increasing her current stock. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who also have businesses dealing with restaurant, clothes sales, snack sales, charcoal and firewood sales.

loans.use: To expand her business by adding her current stock.

loans.name: Mgeni

texts.en:
Mgeni is 47 and divorced with 2 children, aged 20 and 18. She has been a poultry keeper since 2005. Every day, she works from 8AM to 8PM at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $70 from her sales.

Mgeni is now looking for a loan to expand her business.

loans.use: To expand her business.

loans.name: Juraboy

texts.en: A. Juraboy is 52 years old. He is married with 2 children. From the time he was young, Juraboy has learned to work in the family business from his parents. With a lot of sacrifice, he has become a major producer of agriculture in the area where he lives. After he married, he continued working in the same business, watching the business grow as a result of his sacrifice, and saw his family progress more and more. With the income he was able to open a dispensary in his house and raise the cattle successfully. His hope is to continue growing his business to offer a better future for his children, and see them as professional, ethical and hardworking adults. For this reason he is asking a loan of 2500 Somoni (750 USD) for the term of 6 months. He wants this loan to buy livestock, as raising and selling animals generates an excellent profit margin. Be an important part of the growth of Juraboy's business.

loans.use: To purchase cattle and calves to expand the business.

loans.name: Nargis

texts.en: A. Nargis is a 30-year-old mother whose husband has no fixed income. So, to cover day-to-day necessities, she processes and sells dried apricots. She uses all the money she makes to care for her three children and provide for their education. Nargis has 10 years experience processing and selling dried apricots. She is very polite and considerate and her clients are always very happy with the service they receive from her. Because her business is doing so well, she increases her net worth month by month. Nargis requests 2000 Somoni (600 USD) for the term of 9 months. She would spend the loan to purchase dried apricots with the purpose of processing them to increase her inventory. With your help this will be possible. Nargis expresses her gratitude for everyone supporting her and promises to repay her loan in a timely manner.

loans.use: To purchase dried apricots to increase inventory

loans.name: Hadhra's Bread Group

texts.en:
Hadhra is 28 years old. She is married with 2 children aged 7 and 4 years old. She has been a bread seller since 2007. Every day, she works from 8am to 8pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about US$ 70 from her sales.

Hadhra is now requesting a loan to expand her business by increasing her stock. She will share this loan with her subgroup member Eshe, who has a business dealing with charcoal, firewood and coconut sales.

loans.use: To expand her business by increasing her stock

loans.name: Mwanakhamis

texts.en:
Mwanakhamis is divorced with 7 children between 38 and 5 years old. She has been a clothes seller since 1998. Every day, she works from 8am to 8pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $90 from her sales.

Mwanakhamis is now looking for a loan to buy more clothes to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to expand her business.

loans.name: Malik

texts.en:
Malik C. is 45 years old. He learned his profession as a cattle farmer from his father when he was 18 years of age. After he married, he continued working in the same business, watching the business grow as a result of his sacrifice, and seeing his family progressing more and more. 

In addition to the animals, he also buys and sells agricultural goods to raise more profit. With his previous loans, he purchased two more cattle. He sold them already and purchased two young calves which he is rearing to sell. 

Today he wants to expand his business and buy more cattle. He is requesting a loan of 4000 Somoni (1175 USD) which he's promising to repay within 12 months. From the profit of his business, Malik wants educate his children at the University. With your help this will be possible.

loans.use: Purchasing cattle and calves to expand his business

loans.name: Orzukhon

texts.en:
Orzukhon G. is a very hard-working woman and knows that each day she has to give her best effort and all her courage. She is married with 3 children. She works raising animals and feeding them with the goal of later selling them. This activity creates in her feelings of satisfaction because it allows her to provide a considerable amount of the household income.

Orzukhon began making a living in this way when she invested money from a loan over five years ago to get started and with the dedication that she puts forth, she has seen her little stable grow. The care that she takes to feed the animals and supply them with occasional medical visits from the veterinarian has increased their numbers and so now she guides them into the field each day for feeding.

Orzukhon makes sure not to neglect her role as a mother, because she i€™s also very dedicated to lovingly raising her three children, who also help out in caring for the animals, as you can see in the photo, during their free time. She wants to improve her stable and stalls and produce milk in a quantity sufficient for selling it commercially. It is for this reason that she is requesting a loan of 2000 Somoni (600 USD) for the term of 12 months to buy calves and fodder for her animals. Please support this woman who is determined to change the course of her life with dedication and hard work.

loans.use: Purchasing calves in order to expand her business

loans.name: Tran Thi Thanh

texts.en: Mrs. Tran Thi Thanh B. joined TYM Fund in 2007. She invested the first loan in her café. 3 months after her investment, she was earning an income of VND 2 million. Besides this main source of income, she also raises livestock and grows rice. With the total income of VND 3.5 million per month, her family's economy is becoming more stable. Thanks to this change, she has more money to spend on her children's education and can buy more items for her family. For the next loan cycle, she is applying for VND 9 million to further invest in her business.

loans.use: invest in her cafe business

loans.name: Pharmacy, Clothes, Bamboo Weaving, Noodles, Fertilizer, And Construction Materials Group

texts.vi:
Nguyễn Thị Hải: 25 tuổi. Ms: 13.03.0014. Vay : 4.256.000 đồng.
Chi Hải vay vốn về để kinh doanh cửa hàng thuốc y dược và các loại mỹ phẩm. Chồng chị làm thợ mộc ở tại nhà. Chị có một con nhỏ đang đi học. Thu nhập của gia đình chị từ 200.000đồng/ ngày.
Trong nhóm của chị gồm :
<li> Nguyễn Thị Hằng: 21 tuổi. Ms: 13.03.0015. Vay ở mức 4.256.000 đồng. Chị Hằng vay vốn để đi chợ buôn bán quần áo.
<li> Trần Thị Vui: 25 tuổi. Ms: 13.03.0016. Vay : 4.256.000 đồng. Chị Vui vay vốn về đề bán hàng và may quần áo tại nhà.
<li> Trần Thị Hương: 24 tuổi. Ms: 13.03.0017. Mức vay: 3.808.000 đồng. Chị Hương vay vốn để làm nghề đan tre nứa, chồng chị làm nghề điện, nước.
<li> Đinh Thị Hồng: 41 tuổi. Ms : 13.03.0011. Vay: 4.704.000 đồng. Chị Hồng vay vốn để cùng gia đình làm nghề tráng mỳ.
<li> C. Thị Dư: 37 tuổi. Ms: 13.03.0008. vay 4.704.000 đồng. Vay 4.704.000 đồng. Chị Dư vay vốn về kinh doanh lân đạm, thuốc trừ sâu ở tại nhà và gia đình nấu rượu và chăn nuôi.
<li> Trần Thị Thường: 30 tuổi. Ms: 13.03.0009. Vay : 3.808.000 đồng. Chị Thường vay vốn về để kinh doanh vật liệu xây dựng.
texts.en:
Mrs. Hai Thi N., 25 years old, is borrowing 4,256,000 VND to use as capital for her pharmacy and cosmetics store. Her husband is a wood-worker and works at home. She has one small child who is going to school. The family's average income is 200,000 VND per day. Her group also includes: -Mrs. Hang Thi N., 21 years old, is borrowing 4,256,000 VND to do business in selling clothes. -Mrs. Vui Thi T., 25 years old, is borrowing 4,256,000 VND to sell various goods and sew/make clothes at home. -Mrs. Huong Thi T., 24 years old, is borrowing 3,808,000 VND to use as capital for her bamboo weaving business. Her husband works as a electrican and plumber. -Mrs. Hong Thi D., 41 years old, borrowing 4,704,000 VND to run the family business of making noodles. -Mrs. Du Thi C., 37 years old, borrowing 4,704,000 VND to do business selling fertilizer, insecticides, making rice wine, and raising livestock. -Mrs. Thuong Thi T., 30 years old, borrowing 3,808,000 VND to do business in construction materials.

Translated from Vietnamese by Chi N., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To use as capital for various business activities

loans.name: Quach Thi

texts.en: Mrs. Quach Thi G.'s family's business is purely agricultural, and they specialize in raising livestock and growing fruit. In 2003, to invest more capital in these businesses, she joined the TYM Fund to borrow loans. Today, with the assistance of her husband and 3 grown-up children, she plants oranges in her big garden, grows fish, and raises 50 egg-laying ducks. With the average amount of VND 3 million per month, her family's economy is developing in a stable manner. As the next loan cycle is approaching, she is asking for a loan to buy plants, breeding fish, ducks, and fertilizer.

loans.use: To buy plants, breeding fish, ducks, and fertilizer

loans.name: Avaz

texts.en:
Avaz G. has always been a hard-working man, who has made sure, from his young age, that his family never goes without their daily bread. He is a widower with one son. He has a grocery store where he sells different kinds of foodstuffs such as sweets, soft drinks, juices, and other items.

With a starting capital of 100 USD, thanks to his perseverance and dedication, he began this enterprise 4 years ago, in order to support his son and parents. To this date, he is the only support of his son and parents. Today he needs to buy additional foodstuffs to increase the range of goods he sells.

With this purpose in mind, he is requesting a loan of 2000 Somoni (600 USD) for a term of 9 months. He is ready to work even harder, make sacrifices and push every once and awhile to achieve his goal and become a successful entrepreneur. We believe his perseverance and clear vision will become key success factors in his small business.

loans.use: Purchasing foodstuffs to increase the range of goods he sells

loans.name: Le Thi

texts.en: Mrs. Le Thi N. is 35 years old. Joining TYM in 1997, she borrowed her first loan worth VND 500,000 to buy pigs and fruit trees for her agricultural business. After 10 years in TYM, her family's economy is more stable. In their free time, her husband works for other people and she buys and sells rice. With a stable income of VND 2 million per month ($125 USD), her family's living conditions have improved and they can pay for their children's education. For the next loan cycle, she is asking for VND 10 million ($625 USD) to invest in livestock.

loans.use: To buy livestock

loans.name: Quach Thi

texts.vi: Mrs. Quach Thi P. has been in TYM since 2000. After 8 years in TYM, she has borrowed VND 45 million in total to invest in raising animals and plating trees. With this loan amount, she has made obvious changes in her business. Starting with a small model, she now has a relatively big business with many kinds of fruit-trees and animals. Besides fruit-trees, her family grows ornamental plants for sale to local people. Doing this business, she is also assisted by her husband, who is a motorbike taxi driver. Strongly believing in the success of her business, she applies for VND 19 million to buy breeding trees and fertilizer. With an income of 3 million, she thinks it is easy for her family to repay the loan
texts.en:
Note: the original description was in English

Translated from Vietnamese by Khang Ho-Si, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Raising

loans.name: Pham Thi

texts.en: Mrs. Pham T. T. is 45 years old. Before she only specialized in raising animals and growing rice. Then she learnt of the experience of other women in her center and decided to borrow loans from TYM to open a grocery. With the assistance of her husband and 2 children, her business has been going on well. Today many kinds of goods can be found in her grocery: cakes, sweets, fertilizer, etc. With an income of  VND 3 million, she wants to borrow VND 18 million to expand her business.

loans.use: to expand her little grocery store

loans.name: Dilbar

texts.en:
Dilbar T. is 40 years old. She is married and the mother of 3 children. Since she was very young, Dilbar worked on a small farm, and now, along with her husband she works cultivating potatoes, corn, and vegetables. When their crop comes in, they transport it to the capital for sale.

This activity has helped to pay the economic expenses of her family and to give an education to her three children. Today she needs a loan for the salary of their hired workers and also for transportation of her vegetables. With this desire in mind, she asks your consideration to receive them in your kind heart. She requests 2500 Somoni (750 USD) for the term of 6 months. Dilbar wants to thank everyone for supporting her and promises to repay the loan in a timely fashion.

loans.use: Paying the salary of their hired workers and transportation of her vegetables

loans.name: Tran Thi

texts.en:
Mrs. Tran Thi T. is 27 years old and has two children. In 2003, she joined TYM Fund and took out a loan to invest in raising livestock, but this business was not very profitable. Being resourceful and flexible, she switched to the Internet access business, and since this service was new in her area, it became successful. Additional family income comes from Tran’s husband, a driver.

Currently, the demand for Internet access by local people is increasing, so Tran is requesting a loan of $1100 to buy computers to expand her business. With her income of over $185 per month, she is confident that she will have enough money to repay the loan in a timely fashion.

loans.use: To buy additional computers for her business.

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.en:
Mrs. NguY. Thi Y., aged 43, joined TYM Fund in 1997. With her first loan cycle, she borrowed VND 500,000 to invest in livestock raising. As this was the first time she had borrowed money for her business, she did not have experience and had made just VND 100,000 after 3 months. Although it was not a big amount, thanks to that loan she got used to loans and the repayment mode of TYM Fund.

After 10 years in TYM, Mrs. NguY. Thi Y.'s family has experienced many changes. Today besides livestock raising, she operates a milling machine, which is the main source of income of her family. Starting as a poor household, her family now has a stable monthly income of VND 2-3 million. Her family's life is getting more and more stable and they even spend more on their children's education. Concerning the next loan cycle, she wants to borrow VND 10 million to buy another milling machine to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy another milling machine to expand her business

loans.name: Kawthar

texts.en:
Kawthar is 22 years old. She is married with two children, aged six and one years old. She has been selling clothing since 2006. She works daily from 8am to 6pm at her business and earns about $60 from her sales.

Kawthar is requesting a loan to buy more clothing for her business to increase her sales and profits.

loans.use: To buy more clothing for the expansion of her business.

loans.name: Pham Thi

texts.vi: Mrs. Pham Thi C. is 49 years old. Her husband is a soldier and is garrisoned far from home, so she is responsible for all housework and family issues. In 2003, she joined TYM Fund and borrowed a loan to invest in pig raising. After 3 months, she gained a profit of VND 200,000. As a laborious woman, she continued borrowing to invest in raising pigs and plant some kinds of fruit tree. As she did these businesses, she also leant more experience from other people. That is why after joining TYM for 5 years, her businesses have improved and she now has an income of VND 2 million per month. In addition, her husband contributes his salary to the family's income, which makes her family's economy stable. Regarding the next cycle, she wants to borrow VND 19 million to invest in her fruit-tree plating business.
texts.en:
Note: the original description was in English

Translated from Vietnamese by Khang Ho-Si, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Growwing

loans.name: Ngano

texts.en:
Ngano is 49 and a widow with 5 children between 28 and 18 years old. She has been a clothes and food seller since 2000. Every day, she works from 6am to 8pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $125 from her sales.

Ngano now requests a loan to buy more food items and clothes for her business.

loans.use: To buy more food items and clothes for her business.

loans.name: Pham Thi

texts.en:
Mrs. Pham Thi H. is 56 years old. She has 3 grown-up children. Before she joined TYM Fund, her family mainly focused on agriculture. In 2000, she joined TYM and borrowed a loan to invest in livestock raising. Although she had to work hard, she did not make much money. Thanks to joining TYM and sharing experiences with other women, she decided to add start one more business: grocery-selling.

At the beginning, she just sold some types of goods but day in day out her grocery has become bigger with many kinds of items. Realizing that this is a good business, she wants to borrow VND 10 million to expand her grocery shop in terms of quantity of goods.

loans.use: to expand the inventory of her little grocery store

loans.name: Le Thi

texts.vi: Mrs. Le Thi N. is 33 years old. She joined TYM in 2003. At first she borrowed a loan for her animal raising business. Being quick-witted and resourceful, she realized that there was an increasing demand for food and consumer products in her area while there were not many shops and groceries. That was why she decided to open a grocery of her own. Up to now she has run this grocery for 5 years with additional capital from TYM and her grocery is getting bigger and bigger. With the profit from her business and income from her husband, a carpenter, her family has a stable income of VND 3 million per month and their living standard is improved a lot. In the coming time, she wants to borrow VND 15 million to invest more in her grocery.
texts.en:
Note: the original description is in English.

Translated from Vietnamese by Khang Ho-Si, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: buy products for her grocery store

loans.name: Bui Thi

texts.vi: Mrs. Bui Thi S. is 55 years old. Her 5 children are all mature. In 1997, she joined TYM fund to avail loans to improve her family's economy. She used her first loan in animal raising but did not gain much money as she was inexperienced. For the following loans, she invested in her grocery and at the same time still raised animals and grew rice. Thanks to her ceaseless effort, she now has a stable income of VND 3 million. For the next loan cycle, she wants to borrow VND 18 million to buy more types of consumer products to serve local people.
texts.en:
Note: the original description was already in English

Translated from Vietnamese by Khang Ho-Si, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Business

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi: Mrs. Nguyen Thi T. is 50 years old. She joined TYM in 1997 and availed loans to trade jute. However, the economic effect of this project was not high. Therefore, she invested her capital in her grocery. After using loans effectively for ten years, she has even opened a computer shop in Hanoi capital to create jobs for her children. With an income of VND 3.5 million, she not only repays TYM but also save some money as additional capital for her business. Now she wants to borrow VND 19 million to buy more goods for her grocery.
texts.en:
Note: the original description was in English. The "Translated from ..." was inserted automatically by the system

Translated from Vietnamese by Khang Ho-Si, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Business

loans.name: Vu Thi

texts.vi: Mrs. Vu Thi V. joined TYM Fund in 1998. With the first loan worth VND 500,000, she opened a breakfast restaurant at home. With enthusiastic service and reasonable price, her restaurant attracted more and more customers. Realizing that this business will bring about stable income for her family, Mrs. V. decides bravely to borrow more loans to buy some equipments and expand her restaurant. In addition to this business, her family raises 100 pigs. Therefore, she wants to borrow VND 18 million to buy food and equipment for her two businesses
texts.en:
Note: the original description was in English

Translated from Vietnamese by Khang Ho-Si, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Restaurant

loans.name: Jamshed

texts.ru: Расулов Джамшед житель района Хуросон. Возраст 21 год, женат и имеет одного ребенка. Занимается бизнесом. Привозит из города Душанбе стройматериалы и продает их у себя на рынке. Решил получить кредит и использовать его для того , чтобы закупить замки , дверные ручки и другие принадлежности. Это поможет удовлетворить спрос населения , а так же получить прибыль. Погасить кредит планирует в течение 10 месяцев
texts.en:
Jamshed R. lives in Khuroson. He is 21 years old, married, and has one child. He works in business. He brings in building materials from the city of Dushanbe and sells them at the market. He has decided to take out a loan to buy locks, door handles, and other accessories. This will satisfy local demand and make a profit. He plans to pay off the loan in 10 months.

Translated from Russian by Melissa Kniazeva, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase sales

loans.name: Saidmurod

texts.ru: Назаров Саидмурод житель Хуросонского района. Занимается животноводством вот уже 10 лет. Эта деятельность очень распрастранена среди сельской местности. Дело приносит неплохой доход.Поэтому он решил уаеличить товарооборот , путем получения кредита. Погасить кредит сможет в течение 10 месяцев. Саидмурод женат и имеет троих детей, обеспечивает всю семью сам , благодоря бизнесу.
texts.en:
Saidmurod N. lives in Khuroson. He has been working in animal husbandry for ten years. This work is very widespread out in the country. His business brings in a good income. Therefore, he has resolved to increase sales by taking out a loan. He can pay off the loan in ten months. Saidmurod is married and has three children. He provides for the family himself, thanks to the business.

Translated from Russian by Melissa Kniazeva, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: buying calves

loans.name: Muzaffar

texts.ru: Бобоев Музафар житель Вахшского района. Занимается бизнесом. Имеет мясную лавку на центральном  рынке.Скупает молодых , здоровых бычков и реализует мясом. Хочет получить кредит , чтобы увеличить товарооборот , путем покупки молодого бычка. Это поможет ему заработать больше в сезон свадеб. Погасить кредит планнирует в течение 12 месяцев.
texts.en:
Muzaffar B. lives in Vakhsh. He works in business. He has a butcher's shop in the central market. He buys young, healthy calves and turns them into meat. He wants to take out a loan to increase sales by buying a calf. This will help him earn more in the wedding season. He plans to pay off the loan in 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Melissa Kniazeva, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: increase sales

loans.name: Mavjuda

texts.ru: Кучарова Мавджуда жительница района Вахш. Замужем и имеет двоих детей. Возраст 26 лет. И уже 4 года она занимается бизнесом. Привозит товар из города Душанбе и реализует у себя на рынке. Торгует одеждой. Хочет получить кредит для того , чтобы увеличить товарооборот. Погасить кредит сможет в течение 12 месяцев.
texts.en:
Mavjuda K. lives in Vakhsh. She is married with two children. She is 26 years old, and for the last four years she has worked in business. She brings goods from the city of Dushanbe and sells them at the market. She sells clothes. She wants to take out a loan to increase sales. She can pay off the loan in twelve months.

Translated from Russian by Melissa Kniazeva, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: increase sales
